References

1. Central role of the propensity score in observational studies for causal effects Biometrika Oxford Academic. Accessed April 5, 2022. https://academic.oup.com/biomet/article/70/1/41/240879
2. Guo S, Fraser M, Chen Q. Propensity Score Analysis: Recent Debate and Discussion. Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research. 2020;11(3):463-482. doi:10.1086/711393
3. Hansen BB. The prognostic analogue of the propensity score. Biometrika. 2008;95(2):481-488. doi:10.1093/biomet/asn004
4. Igelström E, Craig P, Lewsey J, Lynch J, Pearce A, Katikireddi SV. Causal inference and effect estimation using observational data. Journal of epidemiology and community health (1979). 2022;76(11):960-966.
5. Introduction Engineering Production-Grade Shiny Apps. Accessed April 5, 2022. https://engineering-shiny.org/
6. Jann B. Why Propensity Scores Should Be Used for Matching. Published online 1923:84.
7. King G, Nielsen R. Why Propensity Scores Should Not Be Used for Matching. Political Analysis. 2019;27(4):435-454. doi:10.1017/pan.2019.11
8. Koedinger KR, Kim J, Jia JZ, McLaughlin EA, Bier NL. Learning is not a spectator sport: Doing is better than watching for learning from a MOOC. In: Proceedings of the Second (2015) ACM Conference on Learning @ Scale. L@s ’15. Association for Computing Machinery; 2015:111-120. doi:10.1145/2724660.2724681
9. Lunceford JK, Davidian M. Stratification and weighting via the propensity score in estimation of causal treatment effects: A comparative study. Statistics in Medicine. 2004;23(19):2937-2960. doi:10.1002/sim.1903
10. Match icons created by freepik - flaticon. Accessed October 24, 2022. https://www.flaticon.com/free-icons/match
11. R: The R Project for Statistical Computing. Accessed April 5, 2022. https://www.r-project.org/
12. Ripollone JE. Exploration of structural and statistical biases in the application of propensity score matching to pharmacoepidemiologic data. Published online 2019. Accessed April 5, 2022. https://open.bu.edu/handle/2144/36025
13. Ripollone JE, Huybrechts KF, Rothman KJ, Ferguson RE, Franklin JM. Implications of the Propensity Score Matching Paradox in Pharmacoepidemiology. American Journal of Epidemiology. 2018;187(9):1951-1961. doi:10.1093/aje/kwy078
14. Rosenbaum PR. The Central Role of the Propensity Score in Observational Studies for Causal Effects. In: Rubin DB, ed. Matched Sampling for Causal Effects. Cambridge University Press; 2006:170-184. doi:10.1017/CBO9780511810725.016
15. Rosenbaum PR, Rubin DB. The central role of the propensity score in observational studies for causal effects. Biometrika. 1983;70(1):41-55.
16. RStudio Team. RStudio: Integrated Development Environment for r. RStudio, PBC.; 2020. http://www.rstudio.com/
17. Using simulation studies to evaluate statistical methods - Morris - 2019 - Statistics in Medicine - Wiley Online Library. Accessed April 5, 2022. https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/sim.8086
18. Using the Propensity Score Method to Estimate Causal Effects: A Review and Practical Guide - Mingxiang Li, 2013. Accessed April 5, 2022. https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1094428112447816
19. Wang J. To use or not to use propensity score matching? Pharmaceutical Statistics. 2021;20(1):15-24. doi:10.1002/pst.2051
